Title:
Phylogeny and infrageneric classification of European
Marasmius species inferred from DNA sequence data
Keywords:
Europe, Marasmiaceae, molecular markers, Physalacriaceae,
taxonomy
Abstract:
Marasmius is a large genus of mainly saprotrophic species
living on various parts of herbaceous and woody plants. Around one
thousand Marasmius species are distributed worldwide, but only 34 have
been recorded in Europe. Although this group of fungi was investigated
in Europe from the first half of the nineteen century, infrageneric
classification is still not clear. In order to achieve more reliable
infrageneric classification of European Marasmius species we used
molecular data obtained from species representing all sections present
in Europe, and performed two phylogenetic analyses using ITS/LSU and
ITS/LSU/tefa datasets. Phylogenetic reconstructions obtained in this
work support morphology based grouping of species into sections, but in
the lower infrageneric ranks (subsections and series), phylogeny is not
completely in compliance with morphology. Marasmius graminum and
Marasmius curreyi are placed within clade representing section
Globulares, while Marasmius hudsonii (section Hygrometrici) appears to
be closely related to species of section Epiphylli. Also, results
presented in this study supports previous assumptions that section
Epiphylli is better suited as part of the family Physalacriaceae.
However, additional analysis including more taxa from Physalacriaceae
and related families is needed to support this claim.
